90.heading: Asakawa, Mitsuhiro.
90.title: "Yoshiharu Tsuge : un Homme et son Oeuvre"
90.author: Mitsuhiro Asakawa ; notes et traduction, Béatrice Maréchal
90.appears_in: p. 62-68 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 10 (Apr. 2004).
notes: (Le Manga d'Auteur)

Begins: "Yoshiharu Tsuge, que l'on découvre enfin en France grâce à Ego comme x, est un auteur qui a toujours privilégié la recherche créative. Au-delà des générations et des cultures, son oeuvre touche un lectorat universel. Si elle résonne en nous, c'est parce qu'il a su continuellement maintenir ses exigences artistiques, et que, ce faisant, il a dépassé sa propre solitude, son désespoir récurrent, trouvant le moyen de s'en délivrer en fixant son regard sur les beautés du monde."

English summary (from p. 127): "Yoshiharu Tsuge : a Man and His Works. This artist, who was first discovered by Garo, now finally made known in France by Ego Comme X, has always favored creative research. A secretive artist with a depressive tendancy, Tsuge has not published anything since 1987, but his largely autobiographic work exerts an influence that extends beyond the field of manga, as shown by the numerous cinema adaptations it has inspired. Mitsuhiro Asakawa reveals Tsuge's powerful originality."
Includes bibliographical references and illustrations.

109.heading: Asamiya, Kia, 1963-
109.title: Nadesico. Book two
109.author: Kia Asamiya.
notes: "In this pulse-pounding second volume of the Nadesico series, the Kaguya's crew makes a startling discovery: a space anomaly is actually a missing interstellar cruiser lost years before, the space battleship Yamoto. And pilot Akito Tenkawa pursues a mystery of his own as he searches the surface of Mars for clues to his identity and the origin of his Martian tattoos, which he has no memory of getting. Then it's space ships, mecha, and interplanetary adventure as the forces of the Earth suddenly rise up en masse from their base on the Moon and surround the Nadesico. Nadesico has great space battles, pulse-pounding action, romance, and a glorious sense of fun that lovingly satirizes space opera and science fiction animation."
Cover title: Kia Asamiya's Nadesico.

159.heading: Asch, Stan, 1911-
159.title: All Star Comics Archives. v. 3
159.author: foreword by Roy Thomas.
notes: (DC Archive Editions)
Collects the Justice Society and Hop Harrigan stories from All Star Comics #11-14 (1942-1943).

Stories in this collection were written by Gardner Fox and Sheldon Mayer, and drawn by Jack Burnley, Sheldon Moldoff, Harry G. Peter, Cliff Young, Ben Flinton, Howard Sherman, Stan Asch, Bernard Klein, Bernard Baily, Joe Gallagher, Lou Ferstadt, Pierce Rice, Jack Kirby, Joe Simon, and Howard Ferguson. Editors are Sheldon Mayer and Ted Udall. Brief biographies are presented at the end of the volume.

160.heading: Asch, Stan, 1911-
160.title: All Star Comics Archives. v. 4
160.author: foreword by James Robinson.
notes: (DC Archive Editions)
Collects the Justice Society stories from All Star Comics #15-18 (1943).

Stories in this collection are written by Gardner Fox and Sheldon Mayer, and drawn by Joe Gallagher, Sheldon Moldoff, Stan Asch, Joe Simon, Jack Kirby, Ed Dobrotka, Bernard Baily, Howard Sherman, Paul Reinman, Pierce Rice, and Arthur Cazeneuve, with covers by Frank Harry. Editors are Sheldon Mayer and Dorothy Roubicek. Brief biographies are presented at the end of the volume.

161.heading: Asch, Stan, 1911-
161.title: All Star Comics Archives. v. 5
161.author: foreword by R
notes: (DC Archive Editions)
Collects the Justice Society and Hop Harrigan stories from All Star Comics, no. 19-23 (1943-1944).

Stories in the collection are written by Gardner Fox and Sheldon Mayer, and drawn by Joe Gallagher, Stan Aschmeier, Joe Simon, Jack Kirby, Bernard Baily, Sheldon Moldoff, and Joe Kubert, with one cover by Frank Harry. Editors are Sheldon Mayer and Dorothy Roubicek. Brief biographies are presented at the end of the volume.
